title: Applied complexity theory as the new framework for management and public policy
abstractText:
The main objective of the seminar series was to increase awareness of policy makers to the difference which applied complexity theory can make to policy decisions.

Six one-day seminars, in different policy areas were organised, which included:

  • global governance of new health technologies
  • energy policy and climate change; decision support modelling
  • international relations
  • terrorism and soft targets
  • evacuation after a major disaster.

The seminars were held in London, Cranfield, Lancaster, and Oxford. Speakers and participants included policy makers and academics, now linked as a network. Seminars 1, 2, 5, 6 were video recorded and seminar 4 was audio recorded.

Presentations and recordings are on www.lse.ac.uk/complexity.

Papers from Seminars 2 and 3, were published in a Special issue of Emergence: Complexity & Organisation, in July 2010.

Papers from Seminar 4, will be published in the Cambridge Review of International Affairs in 2011.

Each seminar included a discussion on key challenges and two proposals were submitted to ESRC and EPSRC, the former was short listed and the latter went to interview. As a direct outcome of the seminars, Suffolk County Council invited an introduction to complexity theory and the Royal British Legion commissioned a report on project governance using the theory.
impactText: This was a seminar series NOT a research project. There were no 'findings' as such. However the insights were captured in papers and books listed in 'publications'. findingsText: This was a seminar series NOT a research project. Findings are therefore not applicable. Many insights emerged from the discussions but they were not 'findings'. Several publications emerged from the discussions and collaborations and these are listed under 'publications'. Each seminar addressed a different topic, such as energy, security in the hospitality industry, policy and evacuation following a major disaster. Some seminars were video recorded and can be seen at www.lse.ac.uk/complexity (ESRC Seminars). Others can use some of the insights to change policy especially in the energy and security and emergency sectors.
